title: Alexander Volkanovski vs Diego Lopes 2 epitomises the UFC‚Äôs matchmaking problem
description: Comment: UFC 325 is headlined by a rematch that few are craving, with the UFC overlooking fresh challengers to featherweight king Volkanovski
fullText:
When in a bind, sanction a rematch. It‚Äôs an easy solution for bookers, leaning back into a pre-made rivalry and billing it as its second coming. There‚Äôs a score to be settled, et cetera.

But not every feud needs to be run back. Such is the case with UFC 325‚Äôs main event on Saturday 31 January, which pits two-time featherweight champion Alexander Volkanovski against Diego Lopes, nine months on from their first bout. Back then, there was a lot to be excited about.

Volkanovski was returning to the cage for the first time since being flatlined by Ilia Topuria, who brutally ended the Aussie‚Äôs legendary reign at 145lb. The gold had since been left vacant by ‚ÄúEl Matador‚Äù, who‚Äôd jumped up to pursue (and swiftly achieve) similar glory at lightweight, giving Volkanovski a chance to reclaim his crown. But at 36, that redemption story was hardly a foregone conclusion. Back-to-back knockout losses, one to Topuria and the other to pound-for-pound king Islam Makhachev up a weight class, sparked fears that ‚ÄúAlexander The Great‚Äù was over the hill.

Retirement was now a not-so-distant possibility for Volkanovski and as he squared off against Lopes, a 30-year-old jiu-jitsu specialist who had stormed through the division to earn a title shot, it felt like a gut-wrenching passing of the torch could be upon us.

Instead, facing a boom-or-bust scenario, Volkanovski proved he still had it in abundance. Barring a flash knockdown in the second round, the former ‚Äì and now reigning ‚Äì champion outfought the Mexican-Brazilian for a convincing decision win, with prevailing opinion dictating that Volkanovski ended the fight with four rounds to Lopes‚Äôs one. ‚ÄúAdversity is a privilege,‚Äù he declared.

After a fun fight and feel-good win for a fan favourite, this chapter looked ready to be closed. Yet here we are, staring down the barrel of a rematch not many ‚Äì other than Lopes and his camp ‚Äì particularly craved.

‚ÄúIf you don‚Äôt like it, then don‚Äôt watch it,‚Äù said UFC president Dana White, responding to backlash over his booking of the featherweight title. A typically barbed response from White, his dismissal of wider fan sentiment ‚Äì the litmus test of whether his product is living up to expectations ‚Äì is the root of the company‚Äôs matchmaking problem.

The illusion that the UFC is a meritocracy may be long shattered but not only were there more interesting fights to make than Volkanovski vs Lopes 2, there were arguably more deserving challengers.

Staving off British bias, Manchester‚Äôs own Lerone Murphy had a very valid case to be fighting for the belt next. Undefeated at 17-0-1, ‚ÄúThe Miracle‚Äù is coming off his knockout-of-the-year win over hot property Aaron Pico at UFC 319, which saw him sleep the debutant with a stunning spinning back elbow on late notice. With wins over Josh Emmett, Dan Ige and Edson Barboza already under his belt, this performance acted as a title statement ‚Äì something recognised by champion Volkanovski, who said it was a ‚Äúno-brainer‚Äù to give Murphy a shot at the gold.

Yet he was overlooked, so we go to another contender. In fact, we go to the No 1 contender. Movsar Evloev, similarly undefeated at 19-0, has climbed the ladder from gatekeeper to former champion and beaten everyone on the way up. A relentless wrestler, his resume includes the scalps of Ige, Arnold Allen and Saturday‚Äôs challenger-in-question Lopes, with his most-recent win coming against ex-bantamweight king Aljamain Sterling.

However, that fight was in December 2024. The Russian did not compete in 2025, with a slated bout against Pico for July falling through due to an injury. His inactivity would act as reasoning why White turned focus away from his top featherweight contender, though time out of the cage has not stopped fighters from being thrown immediately into the title picture. Ask Jon Jones, Colby Covington, Tyron Woodley, the list goes on.

Sterling was also an option, offering that champion-versus-champion angle, but Murphy and Evloev would have each felt they should have been the fresh challenge for Volkanovski that fans are desiring. By snubbing them both, a natural match-up looks set to be made: Murphy vs Evloev, probably at UFC London. It‚Äôs a great fight, but one that creates another headache for the UFC.

When one gets their arm raised, the other‚Äôs title credibility will diminish. This is not what‚Äôs needed for a featherweight division growing lighter after the departures of Ilia Topuria and Max Holloway. Volkanovski might be next, and soon. Stars must be built at 145lb rather than snuffed out.

The former may transpire at Sydney‚Äôs Qudos Bank Arena if Lopes can dethrone Volkanovski in what might be the Aussie hero‚Äôs last act in the UFC. He was handily bested nine months ago but with both men a year older, Saturday could go very differently for the challenger, who bounced back in style to finish the dangerous Jean Silva in September.

But it feels like either way, the UFC have booked themselves into a hole when they really didn‚Äôt need to. Featherweight is regularly regarded as one of the company‚Äôs strongest divisions but, as we progress into the Paramount era, there are more questions than answers over its long-term future.

title: Lamar Wilkerson scores 19 and Indiana holds off late charge to get past No. 12 Purdue, 72-67
description: Indiana won its second straight game and gave coach Darian DeVries the biggest win of his first season with the Hoosiers.
fullText:
BLOOMINGTON, Ind. (AP) ‚Äî Lamar Wilkerson had 19 points, Nick Dorn added 18 and Conor Enright scored five of his eight points in the final 71 seconds to help Indiana hold off No. 12 Purdue 72-67 on Tuesday night.

Indiana won its second straight game and gave coach Darian DeVries the biggest win of his first season with the Hoosiers (14-7, 5-5 Big Ten). It came in his first matchup against Indiana‚Äôs biggest rival and on the same night college football‚Äôs new national champions were honored during a pregame ceremony on the same court where coach Curt Cignetti once proclaimed ‚ÄúPurdue sucks.‚Äù

The Hoosiers have beaten ranked Boilermakers teams in four of their last five matchups at home.

Trey Kaufman-Renn led Purdue (17-4, 7-3) with 23 points and Braden Smith added 14 points, five rebounds and five assists. But it wasn‚Äôt enough for the Boilermakers to avoid extending their losing streak to a season-worst three games.

And once again, Purdue sure didn‚Äôt look like itself. Indiana negated the Boilermakers‚Äô perceived advantage in the post, outrebounding them 33-28 while only getting outscored 24-18 in the paint in a game that had all the elements of a rivalry.

Indiana initially took control with a 21-6 spurt to close the first half, turning a 23-21 deficit into a 40-29 lead.

Then the Hoosiers had to withstand a series of second-half punches from Purdue.

When the Boilermakers closed to 47-41 on Smith‚Äôs pull-up jumper with 15:02 to go, the Hoosiers answered with a 7-2 run. When Smith‚Äôs layup made it 65-63 with 1:28 left, Enright responded with a 3-pointer. And when Kaufman-Renn‚Äôs layup cut the deficit 68-65 with 28 seconds remaining, Enright made two free throws that helped the Hoosiers close it out.

Purdue visits Maryland on Sunday.

Indiana begins its Los Angeles swing with a trip to UCLA on Saturday.

title: This Kentucky Basketball team might break an all-time record from the Probation Era
description: Not exactly the kind of company you want to be in, but that‚Äôs where Mark Pope has Kentucky Basketball headed.
fullText:
The Kentucky Wildcats‚Äô 5-game SEC win streak came to a screeching halt on Tuesday night in Nashville, as they were annihilated 80-55 by the Vanderbilt Commodores.

The Dores made easy work of the Cats, who fell to 14-7 on the season.

In what has been a frustrating season in the blowout category, the team is nearing historic numbers.

Per the UK Statistician, Corey Price, the Wildcats surrendered their fourth 15+ point loss of the season, which has them nearing the top of the record books. (In a bad way.)

Over the last 50 seasons of Wildcats basketball, since 1976-1977, these are the most losses by 15+ in a single season:

-4 (2025-2026, as of January 26th)

The Wildcats have dug themselves into early holes in big games and have not found a solution. A very worrisome trend in the Mark Pope era. And with the schedule ahead, it feels like there‚Äôs a very real chance this Kentucky team breaks the all-time mark for losses of 15+ points. They would join the Probation Era teams that were barred from the NCAA Tournament from 1990-91.

Not exactly the kind of company you want to be in, but that‚Äôs where Mark Pope has Kentucky headed.

The Wildcats are back in action on Saturday evening against the Arkansas Razorbacks. A game Pope couldn‚Äôt find a way to win last season, the Wildcats will look to get off to a quick start on the road at Bud Walton Arena.

Over the last 50 seasons, since 1976-1977, the most losses by at least 15 points in a single season for @KentuckyMBB:

‚Äì 7 (1988-1989)

‚Äì 5 (1991-1992)

‚Äì 4 (2025-2026, as of January 27th)

‚Äì 4 (2005-2006)

‚Äî Corey Price (@coreyp08) January 28, 2026

title: Niele Ivey Points to Lingering Notre Dame Red Flag Ahead of West Coast Swing
description: Notre Dame has found itself in quite a predicament after their last few games. Niele Ivey‚Äôs team has won just a solitary game against Miami while collapsing against Louisville 79-66, UConn 89-47, and Clemson 65-58, which has understandably shaken the team.
fullText:
Notre Dame has found itself in quite a predicament after their last few games. Niele Ivey‚Äôs team has won just a solitary game against Miami while collapsing against Louisville 79-66, UConn 89-47, and Clemson 65-58, which has understandably shaken the team. Notre Dame will be on the road for their next couple of games, visiting the West Coast. Now, the Fighting Irish‚Äôs head coach has noted serious flaws within her team, and she demands some swift changes.

Niele Ivey recently joined host Tony Simeone on the ‚ÄúVoice of the Irish‚Äù podcast to share where she feels the team has to upgrade itself.

‚ÄúI think rebounding is a big part of what we need to focus on. Both teams have great balance. Cal is a little bit more athletic. They have great size, so doing a great job on the boards is something that we‚Äôre going to focus on, so that‚Äôs one thing. Offensively, I always want to work on getting better, defensively being consistent, but rebounding is going to be a big part,‚Äù said Niele Ivey as she feels that‚Äôs one aspect where the team can improve.

The rebounding disparity is striking. In their last two losses, Clemson outrebounded them 40-20, and UConn won the battle on the boards 39-24. Moreover California Golden Bears are tall and physical. Sakima Walker, 6‚Äô5‚Ä≥, and Claudia Langarita, 6‚Äô4‚Ä≥, can cause problems in the paint if the team isn‚Äôt careful, and Ivey is well aware of that.

‚ÄúYeah its definitely the individual mindset for sure. But like early in the season, we can do more individual things. Right now, we‚Äôre doing more 5 on 5, so scrimmaging more.‚ÄùIvey clarified that the focus is shifting from individual drills to team-based scrimmages, emphasizing the collective effort she wants to instill in her players.

Notre Dame might have found itself in a black hole, but that hasn‚Äôt affected Hannah Hidalgo‚Äôs game the slightest. The Notre Dame guard has come out as the top scorer in their last five games despite her team not being able to capitalize on her hot streak. While some are blaming Ivey, Hidalgo refuses to blame her coach.

In her last game against Clemson, Hidalgo scored 30 points, nearly half the team‚Äôs total. She also had 8 steals, 6 assists, and 4 rebounds to boot, but it all went in vain. So what is going wrong and why the sudden dip in form since January? This was the same team that was holding a 10-2 record in the season, but the following month saw a completely different story.

Niele Ivey‚Äôs team is 5-3 since January started, and as such, many are coming down hard on the coach. Hidalgo isn‚Äôt buying the accusations and making sure that her team takes accountability for the mistakes made.

‚ÄúTo be clear, it‚Äôs nothing that Coach Ivey can do to bring the level of toughness to us. This is an individual thing that everybody has to bring consistently. ‚Ä¶ It‚Äôs up to us‚Ä¶.. to bring it out of each other‚Ä¶ You wouldn‚Äôt look at any other team, and they say, ‚ÄòWe look to our coach to bring that toughness out of us.‚Äô That‚Äôs not a thing,‚Äù Hidalgo says.

It is fairly evident that the team is very dependent on Hannah to take them through by now, and that mentality probably won‚Äôt help much when the competition gets tough. Except for Hannah, Cassandre Prosper (15.7 PPG ) and Iyana Moore (10.8 PPG) are the only ones who are hitting double figures, and that can definitely be improved because you can‚Äôt overburden anyone with extra pressure.

Coach Niele Ivey has 9 more games remaining and would hope and pray that the underlying complications are fixed as soon as possible. For now, her focus is on the upcoming West Coast swing as the first step in the team‚Äôs recovery.

The post Niele Ivey Points to Lingering Notre Dame Red Flag Ahead of West Coast Swing appeared first on EssentiallySports.

title: Prep basketball roundup: Mission League finalizes tournament plans
description: Sierra Canyon, Sherman Oaks Notre Dame, Harvard-Westlake and Loyola are top four seeds.
fullText:
It's time to see which Mission League basketball teams are ready for some March Madness in February.

The tournament is set to begin Thursday after Tuesday's final results clarified seedings.

Falling down Isaiah Barnes of Crespi delivers decisive basket for four-point lead over Loyola. pic.twitter.com/hCZPhe2sHC

‚Äî eric sondheimer (@latsondheimer) January 28, 2026

The final game of the night was Crespi pulling out a 65-61 win over Loyola when Isaiah Barnes scored while falling down with 15 seconds left for the game-clinching basket. Despite the loss, Loyola claimed fourth place in the seedings while finishing in a three-way tie for fourth with Crespi and St. Francis.

The Cubs, though, are 14-14 and will need a win Saturday against the winner of Thursday's Bishop Alemany (No. 8) vs. St. Francis (No. 5) game to keep alive their Southern Section playoff hopes. You need a .500 or better record to be considered for an at-large berth.

The other Thursday game has No. 7 Chaminade at No. 6 Crespi. That winner will play at Harvard-Westlake on Saturday.

Mission League tournament. pic.twitter.com/Zv9mhwPZoj

‚Äî eric sondheimer (@latsondheimer) January 28, 2026

Crespi was led by 6-foot-9 Rodney Mukendi, who scored 17 points. Deuce Newt had 15 points for Loyola.

Harvard-Westlake 90, St. Francis 56: Joe Sterling got back his shooting touch, making seven threes and finishing with 27 points. Amir Jones added 17 points for Harvard-Westlake. St. Francis did not play center Cherif Millogo.

Sherman Oaks Notre Dame 81, Bishop Alemany 48: The Knights claimed second place in the Mission League and an automatic spot for the Southern Section playoffs. Zach White had 26 points and 10 rebounds. Notre Dame played without NaVorro Bowman.

Sierra Canyon 79, Chaminade 28: Brandon McCoy had 18 points and Maxi Adams added 17 points for the Mission League regular-season champions.

Crean Lutheran 76, La Habra 67: The Saints took over first place in the Crestview League.

Mira Costa 53, Peninsula 41: Logan Dugdale has 17 points and 10 rebounds for Mira Costa (23-4).

A. Times SoCal high school sports newsletter to get scores, stories and a behind-the-scenes look at what makes prep sports so popular.

This story originally appeared in Los Angeles Times.

title: Former LSU Tigers WR Chris Hilton Jr. Added Late To 2026 Senior Bowl Roster
description: The LSU Tigers have concluded their football season and while they focus on next year's team, their now former players are focusing on the NFL draft.
fullText:
The LSU Tigers have concluded their football season and while they focus on next year's team, their now former players are focusing on the NFL draft.

After an impressive showing in the 2026 East-West Shrine Bowl, former Tigers wideout Chris Hilton Jr. has been a late add to the 2026 Senior Bowl roster, per WAFB's Jacques Doucet.

Many scouts at the Shrine Bowl praised the performance of Hilton. It's no surprise, given that this is an environment built for someone like him to excel. The defense is at a disadvantage and he has speed for days.

The Zachary product came to Baton Rouge as a highly sought-after recruit. He was the No. 58 overall player in his class, fifth-best wideout and third in Louisiana. His ceiling always felt sky high.

A number of unfortunate injuries and circumstances kept Hilton from really ever getting the opportunity to perform at LSU. He finished his career with 41 catches for 780 yards and six touchdowns. He had a career average of 19 yards per reception.

If he can stay healthy, he certainly has enough to offer an NFL team for a shot. At the very least, he has the speed for it.

Being brought over from the Shrine Bowl to the Senior Bowl is a big deal. There were 106 Senior Bowl players drafted last season. That's over 41% of the draft. He will have the chance to compete in two practices before the game and the chance to meet with every single NFL team.

This would be a fantastic journey to the league if Hilton can continue to impress.

title: The Champions League is entering crunch time ‚Äî and the stakes couldn‚Äôt be lower
description: There is the live possibility that all six of the Premier League clubs finish inside the top eight to qualify for the Champions League last 16, with English dominance on the European stage reflective of a shift in attitudes
fullText:
In the buildup to Arsenal‚Äôs trip to Inter last week, those at their London Colney training base couldn‚Äôt help notice a shift in mood. There was no tension, it was all rather relaxed. A largely second-string team then carried that onto the pitch by breezing through a 3-1 away win against last season‚Äôs finalists. Long-time club insiders couldn‚Äôt help contrasting to 20 or even 15 years ago.

‚ÄúNo pressure going to the San Siro for a Champions League game ‚Äì imagine that.‚Äù

Needless to say, it wasn‚Äôt like that for the Premier League games either side of that win. And while some of that may be distinctive to Arsenal‚Äôs first place and a complex about winning the title, it is actually a common feeling.

Liverpool‚Äôs many problems have been much less pronounced in the Champions League, where they can still stamp on Real Madrid or go to a stadium as intimidating as Olympique Marseille‚Äôs Velodrome and pick off a win.

Manchester City may admittedly have more angst after Bodo-Glimt, but they‚Äôd probably have taken a home match against Galatasaray to secure automatic qualification before this began. Newcastle United have meanwhile been much less inconsistent, as Tottenham Hotspur have been a force. Most starkly, Burnley and West Ham United posed more difficult challenges than Borussia Dortmund.

And this is where there has been a very definite shift.

One source relates a common view. ‚ÄúThe Premier League is now psychologically and tactically more challenging than the Champions League.‚Äù

The European games are described as much less tense. Crisis clubs now look forward to the refresh of a Champions League week, a total inversion of 30 years ago.

Such claims will almost sound sacrilegious to anyone who grew up steeped in the competition‚Äôs mythology from that time, as this really isn‚Äôt what the Champions League is supposed to be about. It‚Äôs cast as the pinnacle of the sport.

Clubs that properly have qualification in the balance ‚Äì like Antonio Conte‚Äôs Napoli ‚Äì will obviously feel different, but that points to another major factor.

One is a long-term structural issue that these pages have discussed so much over the years. The Premier League has so much more collective wealth, as can be seen with how Marseille‚Äôs total revenue is lower than that of 14 English clubs, and close to half of Villa‚Äôs wage bill. Such forces have created a talent drain from everywhere else. Essentially, any time anyone starts to do anything good ‚Äì and this is especially true as regards coaching ‚Äì they are snapped up by an English club.

The only exception seems to be with the majority of truly elite stars. In what looks like a necessary counterbalance, such players ‚Äì from Kylian Mbappe to Khvicha Kvaratskhelia ‚Äì are still attracted to the glamour of the European super clubs, who also tend to accommodate their wage structures accordingly. Some Premier League figures feel this is the one remaining area where the English competition is missing out, as if it doesn‚Äôt already have enough.

It is very much a coach‚Äôs league, though, as recent articles about the effect of pressing and set pieces on goals have illustrated. Many of the major Champions League clubs don‚Äôt have to think about this in the same way, repeatedly leading to the bizarre scenes of Arne Slot declaring his delight that European opposition don‚Äôt play in a low block.

They might have to start thinking about it if English dominance continues ‚Äì but the wonder is how far that goes.

As we go into the grand television event that is the final group night ‚Äì intended to make all of this worthwhile ‚Äì there is the live possibility that all six of the English clubs qualify as part of the top eight. Arsenal are already all but confirmed as top.

Even if all six don‚Äôt qualify, it says enough that it‚Äôs a distinctive prospect, to say nothing that six clubs from one country is already too much anyway.

There are figures at the top of Uefa who readily complain about how the ‚ÄúEuropean space‚Äù was made impossible by Bosman and an economic context that ensures a concentration of wealth to an ever-narrowing area of the game, although questions could then be asked about decisions made and regulation.

This very Champions League model was partly intended to be a regulatory response to all this, but it might well have had the adverse effect.

So much of the competition feels like the stakes are so low. Even this week, Napoli vs Chelsea is one of the few matches that feels ‚Äúbig‚Äù, but it‚Äôs not like it‚Äôs a straight knockout: Chelsea have the safety net.

It‚Äôs another contrast with the Premier League. For all the bombast of the competition, there is constant noise and narrative around it; with these Champions League matches, many of them feel like filler with little consequence.

Because, no matter how you try to talk around it, even a Paris Saint-Germain vs Newcastle United that is about automatic qualification won‚Äôt feel the same as sudden death.

Take the example of that Spurs vs Dortmund match. Would it have felt quite so forgiving for Spurs if it were a knockout? The energy would have been completely different. Dortmund themselves would surely have looked different, and perhaps prepared a more layered gameplan than something that just felt like it was for a weekly league match.

And yet these strange stakes may also work another way.

It‚Äôs been said before, but there is a considerable irony to how the ‚Äúprize‚Äù for the top eight is to avoid an extra two ‚Äúpunishment‚Äù fixtures, when the entire point of this expanded Champions League is that the wealthy clubs actively wanted more games. Arsenal badly needed a free midweek, so they played for it.

What does that say about the football calendar and its effects?

Hence, a mere two English winners in this decade so far, despite all that wealth. Premier League teams get to the business end too exhausted, and after so much more competitive tension in their domestic league, where the European super clubs‚Äô greater stars finally have that space to excel.

Look at the fate of last year‚Äôs group winners, Liverpool. Arsenal might have to be conscious of that.

PSG‚Äôs victory in the final, meanwhile, only fosters the sense that very little of this matters that much, even allowing for changes that mean knockout home games will be dictated by the table.

Wednesday night will, of course, still be fun. Goals will rain in. The table will constantly change, even if that works against any sense of drama, as there‚Äôs much to keep up with.

The Champions League is supposed to be about so much more than that, though. And it‚Äôs supposed to be about much more than a handful of clubs.

title: Iga Swiatek Speaks Out on Players‚Äô Privacy After Coco Gauff‚Äôs Infamous Racket Break Incident: ‚ÄúAre We Animals‚Äù
description: Coco Gauff‚Äôs emotional outburst at the AO has reignited a broader debate about player privacy. After her 1-6, 2-6 loss to Elina Svitolina in the QF, footage surfaced of the American smashing her racket in what she believed was a private backstage area.
fullText:
Coco Gauff‚Äôs emotional outburst at the AO has reignited a broader debate about player privacy. After her 1-6, 2-6 loss to Elina Svitolina in the QF, footage surfaced of the American smashing her racket in what she believed was a private backstage area. The 21-year-old later expressed disappointment over the moment being broadcast. Now, her fellow tennis star Iga Swiatek has also echoed her concerns, questioning the lack of privacy for players behind the scenes.

Swiatek also made her way out of the competition with a 5-7, 1-6 loss to Elena Rybakina. But during her post-match press conference, she was asked to reflect a bit on the cameras backstage at the tournament. Replying to that, the Pole said, ‚ÄúThe question is, are we tennis players? Or are we animals in the zoo? Where they are observed even when they‚Äôre pooping. Ok, that was exaggerating obviously, but it would be nice to have some privacy. It would be nice also to have your own process and not always be observed.‚Äù

She stressed the importance of having some space where the players can do private things without the whole world watching. Iga Swiatek gave a few examples of courts and highlighted how, at some tournaments, it‚Äôs impossible to avoid people constantly observing them. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think it should be like that because we are tennis players. We‚Äôre meant to be watched on court and in the press. That‚Äôs our job. It‚Äôs not our job to be a meme when you forget your accreditation. It‚Äôs funny for sure. People have something to talk about. For us, I don‚Äôt think it‚Äôs necessary.‚Äù

When Swiatek was asked if she had talked to the tournament about it here, she replied, ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs the point?‚Äù

The post Iga Swiatek Speaks Out on Players‚Äô Privacy After Coco Gauff‚Äôs Infamous Racket Break Incident: ‚ÄúAre We Animals‚Äù appeared first on EssentiallySports.

title: Knicks‚Äô improved defense key during three-game winning streak
description: Call it a players only meeting or don‚Äôt, whatever it was, the message appears to have gotten through to the Knicks.
fullText:
Call it a players only meeting, or don‚Äôt.

Whatever it was, the message appears to have gotten through.

The Knicks have suddenly turned things around following their brutally rough stretch, taking home their third consecutive victory on Monday night over the Sacramento Kings.

Jalen Brunson was terrific late, but leading the way was the Knicks‚Äô improved defense.

Things were evened at 72 apiece through three quarters, but then Mike Brown‚Äôs shook up lineup turned things up and held Sacramento to just 15 points in the final frame.

Mitchell Robinson stayed in alongside Brunson, Miles McBride, Mikal Bridges, and OG Anunoby to close things out and the move worked tremendously.

New York‚Äôs tenacious defense helped limit the Kings to just 40 percent shooting from the field and 16 percent from three-point land on the night.

‚ÄúIt was an ugly game, but our defense stayed solid throughout,‚Äù Mike Brown said.

‚ÄúWe were able to grind it out and find a way,‚Äù Brunson added.

The Knicks are now averaging just 87.3 points allowed during their brief winning streak, and they‚Äôve held opponents under the triple-digit mark in two of those three games.

So, what exactly has sparked this drastic turnaround?

Robinson said one of the biggest things has been their communication.

Brunson, on the other hand, pointed in another direction.

‚ÄúOur attention to detail, our focus, those are big components,‚Äù the captain said. ‚ÄúWe have the ability to be a really good team if we do those things, the little things have to be important.‚Äù

For New York to get where they hope this season, they‚Äôll need to keep this up.

The improved defense will have another very big test right away, as they head to Toronto to face the Raptors in a matchup of two of the Eastern Conference heavyweights in the second night of a back-to-back on Wednesday.

title: Major US sports arena becomes first to start selling THC-infused drinks during events
description: The stadium, home to the Chicago Bulls and Blackhawks, will begin selling the hemp-derived drinks next month
fullText:
The United Center in Chicago will become the first major U.S. sports venue to offer THC-infused drinks during events, reflecting a growing demand for non-alcoholic alternatives.

The arena ‚Äî home to the Chicago Bulls and Blackhawks ‚Äî announced the move on Tuesday in a joint statement with RYTHM, a local beverage company.

The company inked a multi-year deal with the stadium to sell its drink, called Se√±orita, which contains hemp-derived THC, to guests 21 and older at live events, including concerts. The beverages, however, will not be available at sporting events due to league regulations.

"We are excited to introduce Se√±orita and RYTHM to the live entertainment space,‚Äù Joe Myhra, the chief operating officer at United Center, said in the release. ‚ÄúAs we continue to evolve offerings for our guests, RYTHM‚Äôs Chicago roots made its beverage line a natural fit for the United Center experience.‚Äù

Se√±orita, which includes five milligrams of THC per drink, will become available for purchase at the stadium beginning in February.

‚ÄúBringing Se√±orita and RYTHM to the United Center reflects a simple truth: consumers want non-alcoholic options, and leading venues are responding,‚Äù Ben Kovler, the CEO of RYTHM, said in the release.

‚ÄúThe United Center is one of the world‚Äôs premier venues and continues to set the standard for live entertainment with the introduction of these modern, responsible options,‚Äù he added.

The announcement comes as demand for alcoholic beverages has fallen to a record low in the U.S., according to an August Gallup poll. In the survey, 54 percent of Americans reported consuming alcohol, marking the lowest share since 1939. The trend is largely driven by younger adults.

At the same time, young Americans are increasingly unwinding with weed drinks.

In an August poll by Drug Rehab USA, 66 percent of Gen Z and Millennial respondents said they had tried alternatives to alcohol in the past six months, with 24 percent saying they had ‚Äúat least partially‚Äù substituted alcohol with non-alcoholic or cannabis-infused drinks.

title: ‚ÄúThey‚Äôre Gonna Need Him‚Äù: Austin Reaves‚Äô Playoff Leap Will Determine Lakers‚Äô Ceiling, Says Danny Green
description: Early on in the 25/26 season, when the Los Angeles Lakers were flying high, Austin Reaves was one of their best players. Of course, he was playing a supporting role to Luka Doncic, but it was key, and something they‚Äôre missing in their current rollercoaster stretch.
fullText:
Early on in the 25/26 season, when the Los Angeles Lakers were flying high, Austin Reaves was one of their best players. Of course, he was playing a supporting role to Luka Doncic, but it was key, and something they‚Äôre missing in their current rollercoaster stretch.

For now, Reaves remains out with the calf strain he sustained in December and will miss the Lakers‚Äô next game against the Cleveland Cavaliers on Wednesday, at the very least. However, he is not too far from returning, and could very well arrive in time for the most crucial part of the season.

Danny Green, for one, feels that Reaves‚Äô performances in the postseason will actually determine how far the Lakers can go. One thing is for certain, though. Reaves has to do much better than he did in previous seasons.

On ESPN, the topic of discussion was: which player is most important to the Lakers this season, and Green‚Äôs answer was Reaves and how he performs in the playoffs. ‚ÄúOf course, in the playoffs, we‚Äôve seen his numbers have taken a dip,‚Äù he began.

Last season, Reaves averaged 21 points per game in the regular season, but his numbers dipped to 16 in the playoffs. This season, his regular-season scoring has jumped to 26 points per game so far. It is a significant leap, and one that will need to carry over into the playoffs as well.

Green feels that not much will change on the defensive front for the Lakers, even if they sign a 3 and D-wing. So, their best chance to beat teams is to outscore them.

‚ÄúThey‚Äôre gonna need these guys to score a bunch, obviously. Luke is proven, Bron is proven in the playoffs, Austin Reaves is the guy they‚Äôre kind of seeing if he‚Äôs gonna grow and take that next step to being that third scorer consistently, night in and night out,‚Äù Green added. ‚ÄúSo, they‚Äôre gonna need him.‚Äù

The Lakers looked genuinely comfortable with Reaves and Doncic running the offense, but they slipped into a slump once Reaves was injured and LeBron was forced into a secondary scoring role. That is something that has to change in the coming weeks, even if it means James taking a step back to allow Reaves to thrive.

Currently, the Lakers are 28-17 and fifth in the Western Conference.

The post ‚ÄúThey‚Äôre Gonna Need Him‚Äù: Austin Reaves‚Äô Playoff Leap Will Determine Lakers‚Äô Ceiling, Says Danny Green appeared first on The SportsRush.

title: Why the Champions League has become so significant for Arne Slot‚Äôs Liverpool
description: Slot struggled to explain Liverpool‚Äôs poor league form but a strong end to the season will take the spotlight off the beleaguered manager
fullText:
Liverpool have only lost once in their last 14 games. They sit fourth in the Champions League table, level on points with Real Madrid, above Paris Saint-Germain and Barcelona. Their last two European nights have brought away wins over Inter and Marseille.

It is not the whole picture, though; it cannot be, when they are sixth in the Premier League, 14 points off the pace. A long unbeaten run came to an end at Bournemouth on Saturday. It brought a chorus of criticism: the ‚Äúoutside noise‚Äù, as Arne Slot called it. Much of it is concentrated around him. A title-winning manager may have lost the backing of some Liverpool supporters; it can seem so at such times. And if part of the issue is that too many of those 13 undefeated matches were actually draws that produced frustration, Slot is aware that if victories bring respite, setbacks prompt another outcry. Which, in itself, is revealing. The soundtrack can reflect a dissatisfaction with him.

‚ÄúI think it's going to be really difficult to quiet the outside noise with the position we are in in the league so even if we win a few games, every loss or every disappointing result will start the noise coming back again,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúThat's what you can expect if you started the season as we did; not started, but at a certain moment with so many losses. So it's impossible to shut down the noise at a club like this if you are not competing for the league.‚Äù

Which Liverpool are not. Slot pointed out that Liverpool have only won it twice in three decades; as is his wont, he tried to offset talk of their ¬£450m spending last summer by saying they brought in ¬£300m. Yet others of his numbers stood up to less scrutiny.

He argued Liverpool are suffering from competing on multiple fronts and turned his attention to last season‚Äôs Champions League. ‚ÄúThis is not going to be a popular opinion but I am going to tell you: maybe the reason why we won the league last season is that we had to play Paris Saint-Germain in the last 16,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúBecause as you know they beat us and [then] we had every time a week to prepare for our game.‚Äù

Yet when PSG eliminated Liverpool, they were 15 points clear in the Premier League, with only nine games to go; it would have taken an almighty collapse to stop them from becoming champions.

But it can represent part of a picture of a manager grasping for explanations. If the league table never lies, one suggests Liverpool are the fourth best team in Europe, the other that they are only the sixth finest in England. Slot suggested one is the consequence of the other. ‚ÄúI think the biggest struggle we have is that we have to play in both leagues, which is what we want, by the way,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúBut too many times after a Champions League game we‚Äôve lost. A lot of away games included.‚Äù Indeed, Liverpool have four defeats on the weekends after European fixtures, each on the road.

Slot felt exhaustion caught up with them in the final minutes at Bournemouth. They can seem permanently stretched, their expensive revamp leaving them with a squad that was too small and then further reduced by injuries. ‚ÄúIt's almost constantly the same players that have to play,‚Äù said Slot, who is down to one available centre-back for Wednesday‚Äôs game with Qarabag, in captain Virgil van Dijk. Win that, and at least Liverpool have two midweeks off in February and an immediate passage to the last 16.

The stakes for the remainder of their season are considerable. Champions League qualification has a huge financial importance; there is also the question if Slot regains the faith of the more angry among the fanbase and retains it of the quiet figures in the boardroom.

All of which could depend on whether Liverpool find a formula. ‚ÄúI think in between the boxes. we are a very, very, very, very good team,‚Äù said Slot. ‚ÄúBut there is a complete disbalance in how many times we arrive in promising positions and how many times other teams arrive there. But there is not a disbalance in the goals that are scored and that's a very bad cocktail. If we can only improve in one box, then it's going to be probably an acceptable season, but not more than that. And if we can't improve in both boxes, it's going to be a lot of noise throughout the whole season.‚Äù

But what constitutes acceptable? Five months ago, it might have involved retaining the title, or at least coming close. Now that is impossible; so, too, a Carabao Cup run. The Champions League and FA Cup offer the only chances of silverware. Sixth in the Premier League seems unacceptable.

‚ÄúI have my opinion about what is acceptable, but I am not going to share that,‚Äù said Slot. The outside noise, however, will reveal the wider world‚Äôs view. The inside noise in the corridors of power may be quieter but more significant.

title: South Bay Lakers recap: G League Lakers get easy win over Skyhawks
description: After losing five of their previous six games, the G League Lakers managed to earn a lopsided win on Tuesday.
fullText:
The South Bay Lakers continued an extended homestand on Tuesday when they hosted the College Park Skyhawks. They came in with a 6-6 record and looked to go over .500 after losing five of their six previous games.

They fell behind 35-24 at the end of the first quarter and looked to be in trouble. They still trailed 68-60 at halftime, but afterward, South Bay clamped down defensively and held the Skyhawks to just 39 second-half points, allowing it to come away with a 121-107 victory.

Overall, it held the Skyhawks to 39.6% shooting from the field and 28.9% from 3-point range, and it forced 19 turnovers while scoring 29 points off those miscues. Seven of its players scored in double figures, and it had a robust total of 28 assists.

The Lakers' starting backcourt of R.J. Davis and Kobe Bufkin shot a combined 11-of-32 from the field, but they combined for 11 assists against just three turnovers. Rookie Augustas Marciulionis had 10 assists off the bench, and big man Kylor Kelley grabbed 11 rebounds and blocked six shots.

This article originally appeared on LeBron Wire: South Bay Lakers recap: G League Lakers get easy win over Skyhawks

title: ‚ÄòThis one was kind of personal‚Äô: How Utah shook off a poor performance and beat No. 22 West Virginia
description: Three days after a lopsided loss against another ranked opponent, the Utes put forth a much better effort against the Mountaineers.
fullText:
The Utah women‚Äôs basketball team was determined to make up for a humbling, lopsided loss last Saturday against Texas Tech.

No. 22 West Virginia just so happened to be the team standing between the Utes and a get-right game, as Utah beat the Mountaineers 71-64 Tuesday night at the Huntsman Center.

‚ÄúThis one was kind of personal. I think a lot of us had a bad taste in our mouth. ... It‚Äôs not that we brush that loss under the rug or anything, we learn from it, most importantly,‚Äù Utah junior forward Reese Ross said.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs so huge that we‚Äôre able to get another opportunity just within 48 hours. Being able to adjust, it shows growth and determination, trust, and all these things that are going to carry into postseason.‚Äù

The Utes (15-6, 6-3 Big 12) started slow offensively, but unlike the loss to the Red Raiders, they relied on their defense to help them build confidence in a difficult matchup.

West Virginia (17-5, 7-3 Big 12) shot 41.3% in the game, but only 33.3% in the first quarter, and that helped Utah, which gave up 77 points to the Red Raiders three days earlier, lead from the get-go against the Mountaineers.

Once the Utes‚Äô offense kicked into high gear, it was Utah‚Äôs night to shine.

The Utes shot 54% from the field, including 10 of 18 from 3-point range.

The Mountaineers, meanwhile, hit just 2 of 12 3s, the primary difference in a game where Utah led by as many as 18 points in the third quarter, then fended off a rally from West Virginia in the fourth.

And it wasn‚Äôt just the Utes‚Äô ability to hit 3s that helped turned the tide in their favor ‚Äî oftentimes, those outside shots came at critical moments.

The Mountaineers used a 7-0 run to start the fourth quarter to make it a 55-49 game, but Ross responded with a 3, then after a Utah free throw from Brooke Walker, LA Sneed added a triple of her own. Like that, the double-digit lead was restored.

West Virginia cut it to five in the final minute, but again, the Utes had an answer.

‚Äú(I‚Äôm) just extremely proud of our players, our coaching staff, for turning the page after a not-so-great performance on Saturday, and just getting back to Utah basketball ‚Äî being connected, playing with intensity, locked in focus, and just competing," Utah coach Gavin Petersen said.

‚ÄúJust really proud of our players for putting that game aside. That‚Äôs hard to do, especially when you lose at home, but we bounced back and so extremely proud. That‚Äôs a really good team, West Virginia.‚Äù

On the opposite bench, Mountaineers coach Mark Kellogg, who saw his team score 91 points in a win over BYU in Provo last Saturday, said his team struggled to match the Utes‚Äô intensity.

‚ÄúThey punched us early. Stayed with that the basically the entire night. We made a couple little runs there in the second half, but that first half was not very good from our standards,‚Äù he said.

‚ÄúWe knew they would come in disappointed after their last game. Wanted to make sure we kind of match that intensity. We did not.‚Äù

One of those players who set that tone was Sneed, the true freshman.

She scored in double-digits for the fourth time this season, leading Utah with 15 points, just two off her career high. Sneed made 5 of 6 from the field, 3 of 4 from 3 and added three assists in a game that showcased the kind of confidence she is finding midway through her first college season.

‚ÄúI feel like I just wasn‚Äôt hesitating anymore, just letting the ball fly, and obviously it went in,‚Äù Sneed said. ‚ÄúBut also, my teammates just relay confidence in me. And I think just seeing our our offense flow and our defense flow and the flow of the game, I just went in and did what I needed to do.‚Äù

Ross, meanwhile, added her fourth double-double of the season with 12 points and 10 rebounds, setting the physical tone that Utah needed against one of the toughest remaining opponents on Utah‚Äôs regular-season schedule. She also had a team-high four assists.

Chrya Evans (12 points, three rebounds, three assists) and Lani White (14 points, three rebounds) also played critical roles in helping Utah earn its second win over a ranked opponent this season.

Jordan Harrison led the Mountaineers with 18 points, eight assists and seven rebounds.

On this night, though, it was a balanced Utah effort ‚Äî and responding well from a soul-searching loss a few nights earlier ‚Äî that powered the Utes to victory.

Petersen praised his team for their ability to shake off the previous game and its offensive woes that night ‚Äî when Utah shot just 32.7% ‚Äî and show that those struggles wouldn‚Äôt carry over.

‚ÄúYou got to have some courage. You‚Äôre going to make it or miss it, right? It‚Äôs a 50/50, chance,‚Äù the coach said. ‚ÄúYou got to have the courage to be able to miss those shots, and when you get beyond like, is it a good shot, then shoot it.

‚ÄúI think our younger kids are starting to figure that out. It‚Äôs more about the shot quality, because over time and how we train, more often than not we believe it‚Äôs going to go in.‚Äù

title: Nets fall to Suns, 106-104, after teams scuffle late in fourth quarter
description: Mark Williams scored 27 points, Dillon Brooks had 26 and the short-handed Suns beat the Brooklyn Nets 106-102 on Tuesday night in a game that featured a scuffle late in the fourth quarter.
fullText:
PHOENIX (AP) ‚Äî Mark Williams scored 27 points, Dillon Brooks had 26 and the short-handed Suns beat the Brooklyn Nets 106-102 on Tuesday night in a game that featured a scuffle late in the fourth quarter.

After Brooks put the Suns ahead 104-102 on two free throws with 1:23 remaining, a steal by the Suns‚Äô Royce O‚ÄôNeale led to a scramble for the ball in the paint. Brooks tried to wrestle the ball away from Ziaire Williams after the whistle, and the Nets‚Äô Egor Demin pushed Brooks.

Several players started jawing at each other and assistant coaches from both sides gathered on the floor as officials tried to restore order. Demin, Mann and Michael Porter Jr. received technical fouls for the Nets, and the Suns‚Äô Grayson Allen and O‚ÄôNeale also got technicals. Brooks did not receive a technical after getting one earlier in the game.

Allen added 18 points for the short-handed Suns, who ended a two-game skid. Devin Booker missed his second straight game after rolling his right ankle in a loss at Atlanta on Friday night, and Jalen Green also sat with a nagging right hamstring injury.

Porter finished with a season-high 36 points for the Nets, who have lost six straight and 14 of 16. Demin added 15 points, but Brooklyn struggled to find secondary scoring.

When Porter made a 3-pointer with 9:47 left in the third quarter, he had 12 of the Nets‚Äô 24 baskets for 27 points.

Phoenix led 91-81 midway through the fourth, but Brooklyn responded with a 19-5 run capped by Porter‚Äôs 3 for a 100-96 lead with 3:33 left. Williams scored four quick points for Phoenix and then Allen tied it at 102-all with 1:39 remaining.

Nets: At Denver on Thursday night.

Suns: Host Detroit on Thursday night.

title: High school boys basketball: Highland runs away from Olympus in 5A showdown of top 3 teams
description: High school boys basketball: Highland runs away from Olympus in 5A showdown of top 3 teams
fullText:
Highland coach Chris Jones said he believes when teams arrive at Olympus for a boys basketball game, most of the time they‚Äôve already lost before stepping on the floor.

‚ÄúI mean, 99% of the teams that get off the bus don‚Äôt think they can come in here and win,‚Äù said Jones. ‚ÄúSo I‚Äôve been preaching, preaching, preaching for three years, you got to think you can beat them. And if you think you can beat them, then you got a half a chance.‚Äù

Fortunately for Jones, not only do his Highland players think they can beat Olympus, they know they can.

Highland beat Olympus 64-58 on Tuesday night in relatively dominant fashion, its second straight win on the Titans‚Äô home floor after winning 50-47 a year ago.

The Rams led by as many as 19 points early in the fourth quarter and then held off a furious rally by the Titans to secure the region split after Olympus won the first meeting back in December 77-72.

‚ÄúIt got a bit sweaty there,‚Äù said Jones about the fourth quarter.

The teams, who were ranked No. 2 and 3 in 5A coming into Tuesday‚Äôs game, have now split the season series in three straight years.

If they meet in the playoffs for a third straight time next month, Jones hopes Tuesday‚Äôs performance strengthens his team‚Äôs belief that it can beat Olympus in the postseason too.

‚ÄúThey kicked our butts in the state tournament when it matters (two straight year). But you know, hopefully we get a chance to play them again,‚Äù said Jones.

Highland never trailed on Tuesday as it shot 47% from the field led by Jordan Oberholtzer‚Äôs 20 points and Grady Lee‚Äôs 17. Bodie Dodge added 15 points as the Rams improved to 16-2 on the season while the Titans dropped to 16-2 as well.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm just so happy for Highland and the community. They‚Äôve bought in so much the last four or five years what we‚Äôre trying to do,‚Äù said Jones. ‚ÄúOlympus is the cr√®me de la cr√®me. They‚Äôre the best there is. They‚Äôve been the best for 10 years. And so just a chance to be able to compete with them and play with them and give them a game‚Äînot many people give them a game.‚Äù

Highland led by 13-7 at the end of the first quarter, 26-17 at the half and then 43-31 heading into the fourth.

Jones admits his team was a bit fortunate that Olympus leading scorer Gavin Lowe ‚Äî who averages 25 points ‚Äî missed all seven of his shots in the first half and went scoreless. But at the same time, he said it was the result of a much tougher defensive performance than the first time around when Olympus had five players score in double figures.

‚ÄúThey have Gavin, who is elite, elite, elite, but they‚Äôre also big. And they got a bunch of guys that are big, and we got a bunch of guards. So our thought was, we got to pressure them. We can‚Äôt let those big guys just stand around and pass and throw high-low on us because last game they killed us on high-low because we were soft,‚Äù said Jones.

That wasn‚Äôt the case in the rematch as Highland was elite definitely in the first three quarters holding Olympus to 36 percent shooting and just 3-of-16 from 3-point range.

Down nine at halftime, the Titans came out and tried to press their way back into the game, but the Rams ‚Äî who Jones jokes are a team with four point guards and a big ‚Äî handle it well and extended the lead to double digits heading into the fourth.

‚ÄúWe did a great job against their press. I mean, they got a couple, but we scored plenty on their press. And we just wanted to get up and down the court and play with them,‚Äù said Jones.

Highland opened the fourth on a 9-2 run as Oberholtzer and Isaiah Drisdom drained 3s, and Oberholtzer converted a 3-point play after a difficult finish at the rim.

For Olympus, trailing 52-33 with 5:25 remaining was the final wake-up call, and it finally started hitting shots ‚Äî particularly 3-pointers.

Lowe and Caden Jackson both made a pair of 3s over the next five minutes, while Adam Bywater made another as Olympus whittled the lead all the way to 63-58 with 15 seconds left in the game.

The Titans forced a turnover on the ensuing inbounds pass and got a good look at 3-pointer that could‚Äôve made it a one-possession game with 12 seconds left, but the shot rattled out and Highland corralled the rebound to finish off the win.

Lowe finished with 18 points in the loss as he scored all of his points in the second half. Jackson added 13.

title: Sky Germany rule out active Bayern involvement and say Chelsea still pushing to sign player
description: Sky Germany have ruled out any active Bayern involvement in one current transfer deal and say Chelsea are still pushing to sign the player.We are just days away from another transfer window closing ou...
fullText:
Sky Germany have ruled out any active Bayern involvement in one current transfer deal and say Chelsea are still pushing to sign the player.

We are just days away from another transfer window closing out at the weekend, and clubs are scrambling around to get some final deals done this winter.

Chelsea have not really done anything at all yet this window other than a teenage left back from Sheffield Wednesday into their academy. But players sales, nothing, new player arrivals, nothing. There‚Äôs time left, and maybe this means the club will be pretty active on transfer deadline day!

A lot can still happen, and it looks like even the Jeremy Jacquet situation could still spark up. Chelsea have been trying to sign the centre back from Rennes this window, but have so far not managed to.

Jeremy Jacquet playing for Rennes. (Photo by Chris Lee/Chelsea FC)

Sky Germany reporter Florian Plettenberg posted on X last night and said:

‚ÄòBayern are currently not in negotiations with Jeremy #Jacquet‚Äôs management or Stade Rennes over an early transfer in the summer.

‚ÄúBayern are monitoring the situation and remain interested for the summer, but nothing more at this stage. The focus is on extending Dayot Upamecano‚Äôs contract. Other (optional) centre-backs under contract: Tah, Kim, Ito, Stanisic.

‚ÄúChelsea are not giving up. They are pushing hard to find a solution before Deadline Day.‚Äù

Liam Rosenior has he pre-match press conference last night for the Napoli game tonight, and he confirmed that he is due to have some talks with a Chelsea defender who was recalled from his loan spell later this week.

He also said that Moises Caicedo plays like a 35-year-old which is actually a back-handed compliment for the midfielder!

title: Reds' John Sadak calls Miami RedHawks 'such a fun story this season'
description: Former Lakota East standout Trey Perry and the Miami RedHawks improved to 21-0 with a win against UMass.
fullText:
Play-by-play announcer John Sadak is among those impressed with the 24th-ranked Miami University RedHawks' men's basketball team's 21-0 start to the season.

Sadak, the Cincinnati Reds' TV play-by-play broadcaster since 2021, tweeted about the RedHawks after their 86-84 win Jan. 27 against UMass.

"What a night in college basketball," Sadak tweeted. "Michigan-Nebraska. SLU-GW. Michigan St-Rutgers. And an incredibly thrilling Miami OH-UMass game. RedHawks are such a fun story this season. I love college hoops!"

MU is one of just two undefeated Div. I teams remaining, along with No. 1 Arizona. No. 5 Nebraska started 20-0, but suffered its first loss at Michigan.

Reactions from MU to the RedHawks' latest win:

You‚Äôre watching history. #RiseUpRedHawks pic.twitter.com/9u4wKsz7sw

title: Xabi Alonso Liverpool appointment will UNLOCK ¬£87m midfielder deal
description: Alonso can unlock Tchouameni signingBringing in Alonso may well help the club get the consistent best out of both Jeremie Frimpong and Florian Wirtz - two of his best players at Bayer Leverkusen.And t...
fullText:
Bringing in Alonso may well help the club get the consistent best out of both Jeremie Frimpong and Florian Wirtz - two of his best players at Bayer Leverkusen.

And the Spaniard could also put his contacts at Madrid to good use - and help secure a deal for one of Liverpool‚Äôs long-standing midfield targets.

That‚Äôs according to a new report in TEAMtalk which claims that Aurelien Tchouameni could be one of the players arriving at Anfield should Alonso be appointed.

‚ÄúAnother midfielder Liverpool could revisit historic interest in is Madrid‚Äôs Aurelien Tchouameni,‚Äù the report reads.

‚ÄúIt must be stressed that recent claims Liverpool are ready to bid heavily for Tchouameni haven‚Äôt come from strong sources, but there was a mutual respect between the Frenchman and Alonso during their time working together in the Spanish capital, which could aid any faint hopes Liverpool have of getting their man.‚Äù

title: NFL Pro Bowl schedule 2026: Time, TV channel, live stream, rosters for AFC vs. NFC flag football game
description: Times, TV channels, live streams, lineups for skills competition and flag football game.
fullText:
NFL Pro Bowl schedule 2026: Time, TV channel, live stream, rosters for AFC vs. NFC flag football game originally appeared on The Sporting News. Add The Sporting News as a Preferred Source by clicking here.

As Super Bowl 60 nears, the NFL's top players gear up to display their talents at the 2026 Pro Bowl Games.

Starting in 2023, the NFL shifted its annual Pro Bowl from a traditional padded game to a format that includes flag football and a skill challenge. This modification is designed to improve player safety and increase enjoyment for the invited players.

Puka Nacua, Bijan Robinson, and Christian McCaffrey headline the NFC roster, while James Cook, Ja'Marr Chase, and Jonathan Taylor lead for the AFC. The events are scheduled for Tuesday, Feb. 3.

The Sporting News provides all the details for the NFL's 2026 Pro Bowl Games, including TV and live stream info and a full schedule of events.

Location:¬† Moscone Center (San Francisco, California)

The 2026 Pro Bowl has now been incorporated into the Super Bowl celebrations. As a result, all events will take place on Tuesday, Feb. 3. Previously, the game was held on Saturdays or Sundays. This year, it will be on a Tuesday evening.

Flag football game: Tuesday, Feb. 3 at 8 p.m. ET

The 2026 Pro Bowl will be broadcast on ESPN, ABC and Disney XD. You can also stream the game exclusively on the ESPN app, as well as¬†Fubo, which offers a free trial.

Those who want to stream the game can do so with Fubo or the ESPN app. Fubo carries both ESPN and ABC in its channel lineup, and is currently offering a free trial.

title: NBA results: January 27, 2026 ‚Äì winners and losers
description: Tuesday night in the NBA delivered drama, big performances, and tight finishes. Several teams snapped losing streaks, while others struggled to close games. Young stars made noise and veterans stepped up when needed. From last-second free throws to fourth-quarter takeovers,‚Ä¶
fullText:
Tuesday night in the NBA delivered drama, big performances, and tight finishes. Several teams snapped losing streaks, while others struggled to close games. Young stars made noise and veterans stepped up when needed. From last-second free throws to fourth-quarter takeovers, the night had a bit of everything. Here is a breakdown of the winners and losers from all the games.

Washington finally snapped its nine-game losing streak with a tough home win. Alex Sarr led the way with 29 points, 12 rebounds, and six blocks, staying aggressive all night. Kyshawn George and Bub Carrington made big plays late, while Khris Middleton calmly iced the game at the line. Even after getting crushed on the boards, the Wizards found timely buckets and ended a home losing run against Portland that stretched back to 2017.

Portland dominated the glass but couldn‚Äôt finish the job. Shaedon Sharpe scored 31 points, and Donovan Clingan added 14 points and 20 rebounds. Deni Avdija had a solid return with 17 points and 12 boards. Missed free throws and another late collapse cost them a winnable game.

New York owned the fourth quarter by outscoring Sacramento 31-15. Jalen Brunson led the charge with 28 points and took control late. Karl-Anthony Towns added 17 points and 11 rebounds. Mikal Bridges chipped in with 18 points and OG Anunoby had 15. The Knicks forced the pace and turned defense into offense. Mike Brown also earned his first win against Sacramento since leaving the team. Even with 21 turnovers, New York stayed composed when it mattered most.

Sacramento lost its sixth straight game and struggled badly from deep. The team shot just 5 of 30 from three-point range. DeMar DeRozan scored 34 points but had little help. Russell Westbrook added 14 points but could not spark a rally. Their offense went cold in the fourth quarter and they could not keep up with New York‚Äôs run. Poor shooting and weak defense in the final period sealed their fate.

Philadelphia bounced back after a blowout loss the night before. Paul George scored 32 points and hit nine three-pointers. Joel Embiid had 29 points and scored 18 in the first quarter alone. Tyrese Maxey added 22 points and kept the offense moving. The Sixers played with fresh energy after both stars returned from rest. Their shooting and ball movement overwhelmed Milwaukee. The win also showed how different this team looks with its main players healthy.

Milwaukee played without Giannis Antetokounmpo and felt his absence. Myles Turner scored 31 points and Ryan Rollins added 24, but defense was the issue. The Bucks allowed too many open looks from three. Bobby Portis and Kyle Kuzma each had 17 points but could not stop the Sixers‚Äô runs. Injuries continued to hurt their rhythm and depth.

Oklahoma City avoided a third straight loss despite missing several key players. Shai Gilgeous-Alexander scored 29 points and stayed perfect at the line. Chet Holmgren delivered 20 points, 14 rebounds, and five blocks. Isaiah Joe added 17 points off the bench. The Thunder stayed steady during a late Pelicans push. Strong defense and patience helped them close the game.

New Orleans could not finish its comeback after cutting the lead to five. Zion Williamson had 21 points and 11 rebounds on efficient shooting. Saddiq Bey added 16 points and 13 rebounds. Tempers flared late and the flow of the game slipped away from them. Missed chances in the final minutes cost them a third-quarter rally.

Detroit continued its strong run and held off a late Denver charge. Tobias Harris scored 22 points and hit two clutch free throws. Cade Cunningham finished with 22 points and 11 assists. The Pistons built an early lead and survived missed shots down the stretch. Their balance and poise showed again in a tight finish.

Denver struggled with travel issues and missing players. Jamal Murray had 24 points and 10 assists but missed key free throws late. Jonas Valanciunas posted 16 points and 16 rebounds in his return. Fatigue and injuries hurt their execution. The rally fell short after several missed chances.

Phoenix won despite missing key scorers. Mark Williams had 27 points and Dillon Brooks added 26. Grayson Allen chipped in with 18 points. The Suns survived a late Nets run and closed the game with defense and free throws. Even after a scuffle broke out, they stayed focused and finished strong.

Brooklyn lost its sixth straight game. Michael Porter Jr. scored a season-high 36 points but got little support. Egor Demin added 15 points. The Nets could not hold a late lead and struggled with second scoring options. Emotions ran high and technical fouls did not help their cause.

The Clippers erased an early deficit with a huge second and third quarter. Kawhi Leonard led the comeback and stayed steady late. Kris Dunn sparked a big third-quarter surge with defense and playmaking. Los Angeles outscored Utah 36-20 in the third and never looked back. The win moved them closer to a .500 record.

Utah started fast but faded after halftime. Lauri Markkanen led early but struggled later. The Jazz could not handle the Clippers‚Äô pressure defense. Scoring dried up in the second half and the lead slipped away quickly. Another loss showed their trouble finishing games.

January 27 brought strong wins for teams like Washington, New York, and Philadelphia. Young stars like Alex Sarr and Chet Holmgren made a clear impact. Veteran leaders such as Kawhi Leonard and Paul George also delivered when needed. On the losing side, missed free throws and cold shooting proved costly for several teams. The night showed how small moments can decide close NBA games.

The post NBA results: January 27, 2026 ‚Äì winners and losers appeared first on The Big Lead.

title: Dodgers superstar to coach NBA All-Star Celebrity Game
description: Eight-time All-Star Los Angeles Dodgers standout Mookie Betts will serve as a coach in this year's LA-set NBA All-Star Celebrity Game.
fullText:
Dodgers superstar to coach NBA All-Star Celebrity Game originally appeared on The Sporting News. Add The Sporting News as a Preferred Source by clicking here.

Fresh off winning his second straight World Series title (and his fourth overall), eight-time All-Star Los Angeles Dodgers standout Mookie Betts is going to further entrench himself into the L.A. sports universe with an appearance on the sidelines of the Clippers' homecourt, Intuit Dome, in two weeks.

Per the NBA's All-Star Weekend X account, the¬†seven-time Silver Slugger honoree and six-time Gold Glove winner will serve as a coach for the Ruffles Celebrity Game on Friday, Feb. 13.

Among the freshly-announced participants are two big names from the music world, Grammy-winning producer Mustard and hip-hop star GloRilla, the league has announced.

Tickets¬†for the event are available now.

So far, the All-Star Game's 10 starters have been announced.¬†Two-time MVP Milwaukee Bucks power forward Giannis Antetokounmpo, 2024 Finals MVP Boston Celtics swingman Jaylen Brown, two-time All-NBA New York Knicks point guard Jalen Brunson, Detroit Pistons point guard Cade Cunningham, and Philadelphia 76ers point guard Tyrese Maxey have been named to the Eastern Conference's first five.

Antetokounmpo, however, will miss at least the next four-to-six weeks with a calf strain, meaning he'll have to be replaced in this starting unit.

MORE:Proposed Dalton Knecht Lakers trade lands dream $67 million forward

In the West, two-time MVP Golden State Warriors point guard Stephen Curry, three-time MVP Denver Nuggets center Nikola Jokic, 2024 West Finals MVP Los Angeles Lakers guard Luka Doncic, reigning MVP Oklahoma City Thunder point guard Shai Gilgeous-Alexander, and San Antonio Spurs center Victor Wembanyama.

Jokic has been out for several weeks already with a knee injury, and it's possible that he, like Antetokounmpo, could miss out on the action.

title: 'Thiccer Kicker' Harrison Mevis caps stellar season in Los Angeles
description: The Rams kicker missed just one field goal this season.
fullText:
'Thiccer Kicker' Harrison Mevis caps stellar season in Los Angeles originally appeared on The Sporting News. Add The Sporting News as a Preferred Source by clicking here.

While the Los Angeles Rams enjoyed a successful season that ended one win shy of the Super Bowl, they also quietly turned their kicking situation into a feel-good story.

Harrison Mevis, affectionately known as ‚ÄúThe Thiccer Kicker,‚Äù finished a standout year in Los Angeles, one that was fueled as much by patience and preparation as performance.

Mevis was cut by the Jets before the regular season but continued to prepare each week as if he would be lining up kicks on an NFL field every Sunday. That approach paid off. He converted 18 of 19 field-goal attempts, including the playoffs, and was perfect on all 48 extra points.

MORE:¬†Rams predicted to nab star NFC South cornerback in free agency

The opportunity ‚Äî and the results ‚Äî meant ‚Äúeverything‚Äù to him.‚ÄúI think you, you kind of saw the results there,‚Äù Mevis said, according to therams.com. ‚ÄúIt works. It's a lot like golf and you kinda keep it simple and you'll make kicks. Don't overcomplicate it.‚Äù

Mevis credited punter and holder Ethan Evans, long snapper Jake McQuaide, and the protection unit for helping make his season possible. Before landing with the Rams, Mevis spent time with the Jets, Panthers, and the UFL‚Äôs Birmingham Stallions.

MORE:¬†Bills head coach hire of Joe Brady is great news for Broncos, Rams, Titans

Fresh off the conclusion of the season, Mevis said he hasn‚Äôt yet given much thought to his long-term future with the Rams or in the league. What he does know is that he‚Äôll be ‚Äúready to make the next kick, whenever that comes,‚Äù just as he was when Los Angeles called.
